addressFormatDesc: Assuming Western order (street, city, state, postal) breaks for Japan and others that use postal-first, big-to-small (postal ‚Üí prefecture ‚Üí city ‚Üí street).
truncationDesc: Truncating at a fixed character count cuts German compound words in the middle and can break CJK characters. Use locale-aware truncation or word boundaries.
culturalIconDesc: Thumbs up (üëç) means approval in many cultures but can be offensive (e.g. Greece, Middle East). Icons like mailbox may mean 'inbox' vs 'send' in different locales.
numberFormatDesc: Prices and numbers always use one locale's format (e.g. en-US: 1,234.56). They should follow the selected language (e.g. German: 1.234,56; French: 1 234,56). Use Intl.NumberFormat(locale, ...).
ltrLayoutDesc: Hardcoded left/right positioning breaks in RTL languages like Arabic. Use logical CSS properties (margin-inline-start, etc.).
singularPluralDesc: Only handles English pluralization (adds 's'). Many languages have complex plural rules (0, 1, 2, few, many, other).
capitalizationDesc: Uses toUpperCase() without locale. Some languages have different rules (e.g. Turkish ƒ∞/i).
sortingFilteringDesc: ASCII-based string comparison doesn't handle accented characters, different scripts, or locale-specific sorting correctly.
